bibl.title: Is P4, P64 and P67 the Oldest Manuscript of the Four Gospels? A Response to T.C. Skeat.
bibl.note: P. Barc. Inv. 1 + P. Oxford Magdalen College Inv. Gr. 17 (ex 18) + P. Paris Bibl. Nat., Suppl. Gr. 1120 (= van Haelst 336 + 403; LDAB 2936). - There is insufficient evidence to conclude that the manuscript was originally a single-quire codex, and there is no evidence that the original codex (of whatever format) contained anything beyond the Gospels of Matthew and Luke.
bibl.seg: Peter M. Head, Is P4, P64 and P67 the Oldest Manuscript of the Four Gospels? A Response to T.C. Skeat.

P. Barc. Inv. 1 + P. Oxford Magdalen College Inv. Gr. 17 (ex 18) + P. Paris Bibl. Nat., Suppl. Gr. 1120 (= van Haelst 336 + 403; LDAB 2936). - There is insufficient evidence to conclude that the manuscript was originally a single-quire codex, and there is no evidence that the original codex (of whatever format) contained anything beyond the Gospels of Matthew and Luke.
